"Don't fix something that ain't broke" might be the perfect way to describe the problem I have with Hotline Miami 2. I think Dennaton Games ruined the essence of Hotline Miami 2 by trying too hard to make it a better game than the OG, but in doing so, only made it worse by missing what made the OG great, a.k.a. the simplicity. It's not like everything they did with the second game was bad, like polishing the game to a new level, but everything else felt a little bit too complicated, from its story to the level design. As a result, these questionable but well meant choices made Hotline Miami 2 end up as a downgrade to its predecessor.

Hotline Miami 1+2 are two of my favorite games ever made. The music being one of the biggest draws, and the over the top violence being the other. There were multiple times while playing I said "holy shit" from how I either finished a guy off, or from how brutal one of the cut scenes were. Gameplay wise, it's top down, you kill in 1 shot, but you also die in 1 shot. Some levels are brutal, but it's also fairly generous checkpoint wise, so you never lose a ton of progress if you die. I've found the faster and more frantic you can be, the easier of a time you will have. The main difference between this and the first is the level editor, and some people have made some really amazing campaigns with custom music and everything.

Just an amazing game overall I would recommend to anyone.

Final entry of the saga‚Äîand it makes it very clear that there will no continuation.

Far more story-focused than its counterpart, explaining and expanding the world, answering many questions posed by its predecessor while perhaps posing even more... which will never have an answer, I'm assuming.

The maps are far more open, forcing you to learn where every enemy is, lest you get shot by a guy who's not even onscreen, which I wholeheartedly disagree with. Other than that, it's as addictive and hot as the first entry, and as you're forced into the lives of different characters, different playstyles are mandatory.

Is it as good as the first? It certainly lives up to the name; the focus in character development is understandable, though, unless it was hidden and I missed it somewhere, there are so many Chekov's guns left unfired, sinking to the bottom after being thrown into a river for no reason.

It's so very close‚Äîit's nearly there, but it needed one more level or two... or maybe I just didn't get it, or the writers and I have different impressions of what constitutes a masterful story.

It's a no for me. The game doesn't introduce much new content compared to the previous one. I'd recommend it for following the story (which is great) and enjoying the music, if it weren't for the biggest problem with this game: the terrible level design. Unlike the previous game, this one has much more spacious areas, which is the worst possible idea for a top-down game. I spent most of the time shooting enemies blindly across levels. I really love challenging games, but in this one, the difficulty comes from abundant windows, poorly drawn maps where you can't tell what's in front of you or whether it's an obstacle, enormous spaces, and ridiculously dumb‚Äîyet unexpectedly capable‚Äîenemies. Play the first part instead.

One reddit post called Hotline Miami 2 "the best worst" (the worst best?) sequel ever made, which I think is a pretty apt description. It‚Äôs so much more ambitious and polished, with a number of new cool mechanics, an incredible OST, and a varied campaign that‚Äôs 3-4 times as long and climaxes twice, akin to the A/B-sides of old cassette tapes. It absolutely nails the mood of frenetic violence spiraling out of control, and its highlights deserve to be mentioned among the most iconic indie gaming moments, especially Death Wish.

Yet at the same time, it fundamentally misses the core of what made the original work in the first place. It feels like the developers got too committed to creating an unapologetic, unfriendly art project, which meshes well with the themes of crime and destruction but no longer translates into a reasonable gaming experience. It almost feels like a puzzle now, with only a couple correct ways to beat a level and an immediate serving of "press R to restart" whenever you deviate from those. 

The floors got much bigger and more open, leading to long-distance, gun-based action, yet the base design was never adjusted enough to reflect that (including the oft-criticized situation of getting shot by somebody off-screen). There‚Äôs no room for frantic improvisation or spontaneous wins anymore, at least not until you learn the layouts and enemy placements through pure trial and error, and even then it‚Äôs subject to unpredictable split-second variations.

To be fair, a couple of things actually got more consistent compared to the original, like the baiting of enemies or the knockback effect of doors, but it‚Äôs still nowhere near enough to feel in control. And if you go for high scores/ranks, it becomes three times as pronounced, since you‚Äôll be forced to rush ahead to maintain the combos instead of being careful, turning the process into blind repetition until memorization skills and/or RNG take mercy on you.

The story is impressive and memorable once you put it all together, but much less so when you‚Äôre still experiencing it, sabotaged by the equally unfriendly and obtuse delivery. If you want to understand wtf is going on here, you need to remember the first game near-perfectly, down to character appearances and specific dates. You‚Äôd better jot down every date mentioned here, too, or the constant timeline jumps might get you lost quickly.

Also, hopefully, you‚Äôre really good at processing visual storytelling and taking in the scenes, since the most important clues are often only shown in the background while conversations happen. Oh, and just to confirm, you‚Äôre in the right mental state to patiently sit through cutscenes, right? The fast-paced, frantic gameplay didn‚Äôt make you agitated and simply itching to get back to action, right?

Alternatively, you can just play it once, look up the explanations, then play through it again to appreciate the author‚Äôs intent, which is probably what the majority of the fans ended up doing. It really is a convincing, sprawling tale about the endless cycle of violence and its only logical conclusion, and even though the metacommentary is still very on the nose, the extra scale makes it much more fleshed-out and impactful. Going back to the main screen after the credits to realize what that background imagery means is quite an existential moment. Too bad you have to crawl through hours of frustration to experience it.

The same could probably be said about all of Hotline Miami 2‚Äôs strong points. There‚Äôs a thin and subjective line between being challenging and being unfair, but unless you‚Äôre fine with hundreds of retries that rarely feel like your fault, this sequel will likely be the latter.

It's a no for me. The game doesn't introduce much new content compared to the previous one. I'd recommend it for following the story (which is great) and enjoying the music, if it weren't for the biggest problem with this game: the terrible level design. Unlike the previous game, this one has much more spacious areas, which is the worst possible idea for a top-down game. I spent most of the time shooting enemies blindly across levels. I really love challenging games, but in this one, the difficulty comes from abundant windows, poorly drawn maps where you can't tell what's in front of you or whether it's an obstacle, enormous spaces, and ridiculously dumb‚Äîyet unexpectedly capable‚Äîenemies. Play the first part instead.

One reddit post called Hotline Miami 2 "the best worst" (the worst best?) sequel ever made, which I think is a pretty apt description. It‚Äôs so much more ambitious and polished, with a number of new cool mechanics, an incredible OST, and a varied campaign that‚Äôs 3-4 times as long and climaxes twice, akin to the A/B-sides of old cassette tapes. It absolutely nails the mood of frenetic violence spiraling out of control, and its highlights deserve to be mentioned among the most iconic indie gaming moments, especially Death Wish.

Yet at the same time, it fundamentally misses the core of what made the original work in the first place. It feels like the developers got too committed to creating an unapologetic, unfriendly art project, which meshes well with the themes of crime and destruction but no longer translates into a reasonable gaming experience. It almost feels like a puzzle now, with only a couple correct ways to beat a level and an immediate serving of "press R to restart" whenever you deviate from those. 

The floors got much bigger and more open, leading to long-distance, gun-based action, yet the base design was never adjusted enough to reflect that (including the oft-criticized situation of getting shot by somebody off-screen). There‚Äôs no room for frantic improvisation or spontaneous wins anymore, at least not until you learn the layouts and enemy placements through pure trial and error, and even then it‚Äôs subject to unpredictable split-second variations.

To be fair, a couple of things actually got more consistent compared to the original, like the baiting of enemies or the knockback effect of doors, but it‚Äôs still nowhere near enough to feel in control. And if you go for high scores/ranks, it becomes three times as pronounced, since you‚Äôll be forced to rush ahead to maintain the combos instead of being careful, turning the process into blind repetition until memorization skills and/or RNG take mercy on you.

The story is impressive and memorable once you put it all together, but much less so when you‚Äôre still experiencing it, sabotaged by the equally unfriendly and obtuse delivery. If you want to understand wtf is going on here, you need to remember the first game near-perfectly, down to character appearances and specific dates. You‚Äôd better jot down every date mentioned here, too, or the constant timeline jumps might get you lost quickly.

Also, hopefully, you‚Äôre really good at processing visual storytelling and taking in the scenes, since the most important clues are often only shown in the background while conversations happen. Oh, and just to confirm, you‚Äôre in the right mental state to patiently sit through cutscenes, right? The fast-paced, frantic gameplay didn‚Äôt make you agitated and simply itching to get back to action, right?

Alternatively, you can just play it once, look up the explanations, then play through it again to appreciate the author‚Äôs intent, which is probably what the majority of the fans ended up doing. It really is a convincing, sprawling tale about the endless cycle of violence and its only logical conclusion, and even though the metacommentary is still very on the nose, the extra scale makes it much more fleshed-out and impactful. Going back to the main screen after the credits to realize what that background imagery means is quite an existential moment. Too bad you have to crawl through hours of frustration to experience it.

The same could probably be said about all of Hotline Miami 2‚Äôs strong points. There‚Äôs a thin and subjective line between being challenging and being unfair, but unless you‚Äôre fine with hundreds of retries that rarely feel like your fault, this sequel will likely be the latter.
